hypothesis.title: Two-Layer Tuning Effect in Controlled Harmonic Traversal
hypothesis.question: When one fixed arrangement is rendered in Golden ratio algebraic tuning (phi-octave Sbeta5), Golden ratio algebraic tuning (phi-octave SN), and 12-tone Equal Temperament (12TET), do consonance/roughness ratings diverge by tuning while continuity ratings remain tied to shared voice-leading path structure?
hypothesis.hypothesis: If only tuning is changed across otherwise identical renders, then consonance and roughness ratings will separate by tuning arm, with the strongest divergence in tritone-rich bars, while continuity ratings across sections with the same transformational path will remain comparatively stable. This is expected because interval-ratio and temperament error distribution alter beating and difference-tone behavior, whereas transformational/topological path identity constrains perceived harmonic continuity.
hypothesis.rationaleMd:
The sources support a two-layer interpretation of harmony perception. Layer 1 is acoustic ratio behavior: consonance/roughness depends on ratio simplicity, periodicity, and temperament mismatch, and tritone treatment is a known fault line across systems [S1, S2, S6]. Layer 2 is structural continuity: harmonic motion can be represented as geometric/topological paths whose identity is partly independent of exact tuning values [S4, S8].

A potential conflict exists between physically grounded claims (ratio/periodicity mechanisms) and cognitively grounded claims (historical pitch-space learning and line-of-fifths organization) [S2, S7]. This protocol resolves the conflict by measuring both: local roughness/consonance (acoustic layer) and section-level continuity (structural-cognitive layer).

Falsification criteria: (1) no consistent arm-level separation in roughness/consonance; (2) no tritone-window amplification of differences; or (3) continuity ratings vary as strongly by tuning arm as roughness does, contradicting the proposed layer split.

recipe.title: TriTone Window + Topology-Controlled Blind Comparison
recipe.bodyMd:
## Goal
Test whether tuning system changes mostly affect local sensory roughness/consonance while leaving structural continuity tied to shared path design [S1, S2, S4, S8].

## Arrangement Design (single MIDI source)
Use one 36-bar form at 82 BPM, 4/4, split into three analytical windows:
- Bars 1-12: Diatonic corridor (fifths-range constrained vocabulary) to establish baseline stability [S7].
- Bars 13-24: Tritone window with repeated pivot material (e.g., half-diminished to dominant region) to maximize sensitivity to tuning-dependent stress [S2, S6, S8].
- Bars 25-36: Symmetry loop preserving transformational path class while re-voicing surface sonorities (L/P/R-like or equivalent contextual moves) [S4, S8].

Render the exact same MIDI, instruments, automation, and mix in three tuning arms:
A) Golden ratio algebraic tuning (phi-octave Sbeta5),
B) Golden ratio algebraic tuning (phi-octave SN),
C) 12TET reference [S1].

## Evaluation Rubric
For each render, collect 1-7 ratings at section level for:
- Consonance
- Roughness/beating
- Continuity of harmonic motion

Then annotate bar-level peaks of roughness and classify them by window (baseline, tritone, symmetry). Evidence expectation: largest arm separation appears in tritone window; continuity rank should be more stable across arms than roughness rank if the two-layer model is correct [S2, S4, S8].

parameters.value: Sustained triadic/seventh texture with fixed register and voicing plan

details.objective: maximize comparability of beating and continuity judgments

parameters.value: Golden ratio algebraic tuning (phi-octave, 8-note scale Sbeta5)
Golden ratio algebraic tuning (phi-octave, 10-note scale SN)
1-7 Likert per window and global pass

dawChecklist: Create one locked master MIDI arrangement with 36 bars and three labeled windows.
Keep instrument patch, FX chain, automation, and pan law identical for all arms.
Implement Arm A retuning: phi-octave Sbeta5.
Implement Arm B retuning: phi-octave SN.
Render all arms with identical export settings and bit depth.
Loudness-match exports to remove gain bias before listening.
Blind-label files as X/Y/Z and randomize playback order per listener.
Collect section-level 1-7 scores for consonance, roughness, and continuity.
Mark exact bars where roughness peaks occur; tag by analytical window.
Compute per-arm medians and rank stability across listeners.
Accept hypothesis only if roughness/consonance separate by arm and continuity is relatively arm-stable.

protocol.listeningContext: Quiet room at fixed SPL; run each listener on headphones first and monitors second.
protocol.listeningMethod: Blinded within-subject comparison with randomized order and window-level scoring sheet.
whatVaries: Tuning arm (phi-octave Sbeta5 vs phi-octave SN vs 12TET)

notes: Strengthened manual synthesis emphasizing a two-layer model (acoustic vs structural), tritone stress-window analysis, and explicit falsification conditions.
